entry.title: Combined summary - Decentralizing ming
entry.summary: The email thread discusses various topics related to Bitcoin development. The author discusses the concept of "acceptable" in regards to Bitcoin mining, and while there is disagreement on whether marketing a 40% solution is a good idea, the author believes it is a positive step in the right direction. However, the more critical issue is developing technical solutions for decentralized transaction selection and other aspects of SPOF-proofing mining.In a conversation between Jeff Garzik and slush in 2014, Garzik noted that Satoshi Nakamoto appeared to be displeased with the early emergence of GPU mining pools, though he left the project before mining pools gained traction. Later, there is a discussion about set reconciliation and how it can help with communication between peers who have different sets of transactions in a block. Bloom filters are compared to set reconciliation, with set reconciliation being deemed more efficient.There are proposals being discussed to make transaction selection more independent from hashpower. The author provides a historical note on Satoshi's views on GPU mining pools and the potential devolvement of the network to a few big players at VISA/MC transaction levels. Jeff Garzik responds to this message by discussing Satoshi Nakamoto's desire to postpone GPU mining as long as possible to ensure an even distribution of coins. However, this comment was made before pooled mining existed.The email thread discusses the problem of set reconciliation and suggests applying a scheme from Cornell to the Bitcoin p2p protocol to reduce packet size. There is consensus on the need for a "keep bitcoin free and open" technical solution, but it remains to be seen how much engineers can do to make life fair. Firstly, there is a suggestion to use getblocktemplate support in various tools to allow for pooling without giving up control of block creation. The hope is that this will encourage miners to run their own nodes and turn pools into mere payout trackers rather than block selectors. This would democratize transaction selection and take power away from miners.Overall, the email thread covers various topics related to Bitcoin development, including the concept of "acceptable" in regards to Bitcoin mining, Satoshi Nakamoto's views on GPU mining pools, proposals for making transaction selection more independent from hashpower, and the problem of set reconciliation.
